**May contain minor spoilers**

An attempt is made to humanize the conspirators, namely Mrs. Surrat, but does so to little effect.  We see no real connection between her and her children, only a story of their drunken father and her attempts to make a living told within the cold stone walls of her prison cell.

Whether she was guilty or not, we may never truly know.  Many versions of her story abound, but in the end, history is written from the standpoint of the victors. We all know - or should know - that.  Evidence has even been presented suggesting Boothe survived long after Lincoln's assassination, evidence with historical backing, but like the evidence in Surrat's case, it has been buried once more.

This could easily turn into an argument of defending assassins, conspirators and such, but the greatest lesson to come from this movie remains.  That lesson is that from Mrs. Surrat's trial came the defense of one of our greatest rights:  The right to a trial by jury in peacetime OR war.  She may have been guilty, but the process of her trial was unfair and unconstitutional.

I don't "blame the government" as some one star reviewers suggest. I'm not anti-government. In fact, I am grateful that at long last, decent officials finally realized the injustice of Mrs. Surrat's trial and they agreed to stand for the rights of all by declaring trials like hers would not happen again.

This movie should be viewed as entertainment first, given historical inaccuracies (even the best historical movie has them), but secondly as a chance for us to delve deeper into history. Movies like this one should prompt us to think, to discuss and more importantly to LEARN not just the "victor's" point of view, but also the "loser's."

All that said, please allow me to interject what I feel is a bit of humor.  At 1:07 in the movie, listen for the modern sounding toilet as Aiken waits to speak with Johnson.  It's just a wee bit out of place, don't you think?

This film barely made it to cinema release in the UK and despite having a sterling cast and a director in Robert Redford seems to have received little attention generally on the eastern side of the Atlantic.

Redford has always been a politically engaged individual who has made political films. He showed with the exquiste "A river runs through it" that he was confident enough with a story to take his time with it, and with the, in my view, very underrated "Lions for lambs" that he was not afraid of making films about ideas that also discuss ideas in some detail.

These elements are drawn together in this movie which explores a dark coda to the Lincoln assasination: the military tribunal which tried the conspirators. The film focuses upon Fredrick Aiken, a former Union officer and lawyer, who is drawn, rather against his will, into defending one of the alleged conspirators, Mary Surrat, the owner of the boarding house where John Wilkes Booth met with his co-conspirators.

This facinating story is not well known, and Redford has drawn from it clear parallels with some of the contemporary abuses of American power that wartime has brought.

I think James McAvoy is one of the most exciting actors alive and here he delivers one of his trademark ham-free performances as Aiken. The rest of the international cast delivers fine support, particularly the great Kevin Kline, brilliantly convincing as Edwin Stanton, the War Secretary, whose single-mindedness in prosecuting the war to preserve the Union threatens the very principles of the Union in the absence of Lincoln's wise authority.

In summary this is a thoughtful, tense and at times very moving courtroom and civil war drama that celebrates moral courage where others have focussed on the physical variety. Vastly better than most of what is available at the multiplex of a weekend.

In a court of law, Redford wouldn't be convicted of exactly rewriting history, but he is guilty of a more refined crime... re-proportioning events to change the perception of history - thus rewriting history, in effect. The conspirators were, in fact, all guilty. A great place to start learning about the conspirators is James L. Swanson's illustrated history, Lincoln's Assassins: Their Trial and Execution. Mary Surratt WAS, in fact, accorded due process... the due process of 1865! I'm constantly amazed that people of today fail to see the simple fact that the due process, or ANY thinking, for that matter was different 147 years ago than that of today. We've come a long way since then, and it is a huge mistake to overlay 21st century morality on people of another time. They were product of their world and experiences, just as we are product of ours. It is just that simple.

Not long ago, I discovered that The Conspirator was available on Amazon Instant Video. Huzzah, I thought. I had the house to myself and I figured it was the perfect time to enjoy a Civil War era film. I made it through twenty minutes and turned it off.

Keep in mind, I have never walked out on or turned off any Civil War film. Ever. And I have sat through Gods and Generals TWICE. Clearly I am committed to Hollywood's take on this epic historical event. But I just could not stomach this wretched piece of rubbish.

If the first twenty minutes were any indication of things to come in the rest of the film, then I suppose I would have been treated to more over-wrought testaments to "American" jurisprudence - the right to a trial by one's peers and the notion of innocence before guilt can be established without any element of doubt. Thanks for the elementary lesson in  law.

But wait, there are more lessons to be learned here. Yes - Mary Surratt was indeed a woman. Her implication in the murder of Abraham Lincoln and her subsequent execution were shocking to be sure. Thanks for the elementary lesson in nineteenth-century gender assumptions.

The problem, at least in the first few scenes that I could watch, is that both of these issues are of great significance - then and now - but they were glossed over in a tisk-tisk fashion only after dripping a taste of sickening "look-at-how-we've-progressed-but-there's-still-work-to-be-done" syrup on for good measure. And even this was done so in a mumbly dead-pan stumble fest. Such nonsense can only refelct some of the worst writing, the worst acting, the worst directing, or a combination of the three. I would have been more riveted watching a plate of white toast get stale as time slowly, painfully passed.

Not that the film was completely lacking in merits. I got a bit of a chuckle at the actor who played John Wilkes Booth. With all the southern-Gothic charm of a junior high production of Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, his brutish pronunciation of the Virginia state motto in the Ford's Theatre scene - sic semper tyrannis - was delightful. I suppose this was merely an effort to "southernize" or if you like, "Rebelize" the president's assassin (who was not a redneck but a classically trained actor), by giving him a slightly raspier Jethro Bodine-esque accent. Such clumsy and obvious efforts make me laugh.

But who knows? Maybe the utter brilliance of rest of the film made up for the first twenty minutes. I will never know. Perhaps it got slightly less patronizingly preachy. Maybe there was a musical number. Maybe robots. If anyone has seen the whole thing, chime in.

With compliments,

Keith

Review of The Conspirator
Hot Toasty Rag, September 25, 2017

The Conspirator is a courtroom drama about those involved in Abraham Lincolns assassination. Major history buffs might already know the tidbits presented in this story, but I was a political science major in college, and even I was surprised by parts of the plot.

Seven men are on trial, as well as one woman, the mother of one of the co-conspirators. The only man who steps up as a defense lawyer for the accused is the young and inexperienced James McAvoy, and he comes across countless obstacles as he tries to give Robin Wright her right to a fair trial.

If you didn't know Robert Redford directed this movie, you would probably think to yourself, James McAvoy must really like Robert Redford! As it is, Im sure he does like Robert Redford, as does the rest of the all-star cast, since stars famously vie to work for the father of Sundance. If you close your eyes during some of the courtroom speeches, it almost sounds like Redford himself is talking. I think the directorial influence on the leading actor is rather cute, and its easy to imagine that had this movie been made thirty years earlier, the defense lawyer would probably have been blond.

The Conspirator has beautiful, realistic set and costume design, and the men in the castMcAvoy, Kevin Kline, Tom Wilkinson, and Colm Meaneyseem authentic in their surroundings. My biggest complaint about the film are the ladies. Neither Robin Wright, nor Evan Rachel Wood, and especially not Alexis Bledel, seem like they belonged in the 1860s. Trying to ignore Bledels contemporary face and voice is impossible, but thankfully she has a very tiny part. Wood also feels very contemporary, the way she moves and the patter of her speech. And even though Wright has a plain face and doesnt sound like a California valley girl, she still seems contemporary. Women were treated differently back then, and a woman her age would have a completely different aura from decades of living in the 1800s. Wright feels like an independent woman who has never been mistreated or disrespected.

That criticism aside, if you like that era of history, this is a very good movie to watch. Robert Redford is an excellent director, and its very fun to see McAvoy project his essence in the lead role.

When it comes to the story of Mary Surratt, everyone knows how the story ends.  You may not know the name, but you will recall who she was:  she ran the boarding house in which John Wilkes Booth & his cronies devised plans to assassinate President Abraham Lincoln, Vice President Andrew Johnson and Secretary of State William Seward.  {While it was not mentioned in the movie, I believe they also conspired to assassinate Ulysses S. Grant as well}.  Everyone assumed that she "had" to know what was going on, given that she owned the boarding house.

While everyone knows how the story ends,  almost nobody outside the esoteric realm of civil war era historians are familiar with the intricacies of her case.......until now.  The present movie takes the viewer back in time to 1865.  The civil war is over, but it will claim one last high ranking casualty:  Abraham Lincoln.  Seward was stabbed several times, but he lived.  Andrew Johnson escaped the plot to kill him unscathed.  The entire country wanted revenge.  There was also a fear that anything short of a swift show of might would embolden other southerners to try an insurrection.  These were delicate times.

Such is the backdrop of the present movie.  It questions where a person's right to a fair trial is usurped by that nagging variable known as political expediency.  Should anyone ever be used as a judicial sacrificial lamb?  The storyline has obvious overtones which parallel our own times.  We have a great many people accused of terrorism that we are holding @ Gitmo.  They are not even American citizens.  Do they have rights?  If so, what rights to we grant them?  When we have pundits on FOX NEWS espousing that we should just "skip the trials & shoot them" the didactic point of the present movie strikes home.

For people who have read Plato and / or have an interest in the concept of justice, this disc is highly recommended.  For civil era buffs, this film is an absolute must-have.  Was Mary Surratt guilty or innocent?  You decide ~ but watch this movie 1st.

About Mary Surrat and more...A timely review of a situation where the state of emergency in the country allowed the military to take over the trial of civilian suspects. In ex parte Milligan, the United States Supreme Court held that the Habeas Corpus Suspension Act that had been in place since 1864 -  did not itself authorize trial by military tribunals, and that neither the Act nor the laws of war permitted the imposition of martial law when civilian courts were open and operating unimpeded.
 The Guantanamo Bay situation raised similar issues though the laws had been clarified-once more- by President Andrew Johnson's issuance of Proclamation 148 that lifted the suspension at the end of the civil war.
I suspect Mr. Redford is not indifferent to the parallels of what is happening at the present moment.

I applaud the creators of the film for attempting to be as historically accurate as possible, but I was disappointed that nothing was portrayed about Lincoln's Vice President, Andrew Johnson, in the film.  He played a very important part in Mary Surratt's story, and in the assassination of Lincoln.  Much pressure was placed on him to commute Mary's sentence to imprisonment, many military officers and politicians didn't want the stigma of executing a woman.  Mary's daughter Anna, as well as family members of the others accused, attempted to plead their case with Andrew Johnson at the White House several times, but were refused admittance.  Also, on the day of the assassination John Wilkes Booth left a calling card in Andrew Johnson's "message box" at the hotel he was living at, and it's always been a mystery as to what connection he had with Booth.  Not to mention the fact that Andrew Johnson was supposed to be the third government official to be assassinated in the conspiracy... (with Lincoln and Seward) but his would-be assassin "chickened out" at the last minute.  All of this history was left out of the film.  For that reason I give the film a 4 instead of a 5.

3 1/2 stars -- this is a nice costume drama with a timely flavor, but it lacks a bit in intensity.  It's the story of Mary Surratt (Robin Wright), mother of one of the conspirators in Lincoln's assassination (and the attempted assassination of the Vice-President and Secretary of State), and the effort to defend her by the young lawyer (and former Union officer) Frederick Aiken (James McAvoy).  It becomes clear early to Aiken that the government wants to execute Surratt as a way of discouraging those few Confederate soldiers who are continuing to fight on, even after Lee's surrender.  I call it timely, for at the time of its release in 2010, the issue in the US was very much the question of what was justified in the name of national security, as the former members of the Bush administration sought to justify harsh measures and even torture against terrorist suspects and to justify too the treatment of them in special courts outside the civilian justice system.  In "The Conspirator," there is also military court, and it seems quite obvious that Aiken's maneuvering as a defense lawyer is going to be quite limited.  It doesn't help that Secretary of War Edwin Stanton (Kevin Kline) has his thumb firmly on the scales of justice, and it is he who articulates quite unapologetically the idea that since the Union is still in danger, justice might have to take a back seat to expediency.  He's not above pressuring witnesses and suborning perjury, and as Aiken tries to defend his client in these circumstances, his own loyalty comes into question, despite his having been a wounded and honorably-serving veteran.  By the end, suffice it to say, Aiken is thoroughly disillusioned by the law and its susceptibility to political manipulation.

These issues are important, so it's a pity that the movie is so low-key.  Nobody does a bad job -- with Robin Wright being perhaps the most compelling performer -- but it seems more interested in setting out the issues than in engaging us with them vividly via drama.  A movie like this should make its points, of course, but when, in the course of the movie, you feel the points being checked off, then something is missing.  Robert Redford directs with efficiency, and the story lines are clear, but in his earlier "Quiz Show," for example, the legal setting and the acting generated some heat.  Here we have light without the heat, and if it's not really all that bad, it's nonetheless not up to Redford's best or the best of the very fine cast, whom we've seen being much more engaging in other movies.

Anyone with a passing knowledge of American history knows that Abraham Lincoln was assassinated by actor John Wilkes Booth. What ISN'T commonly known is that Booth was part of a ring of Confederate conspirators.

And one of the most important trials of the 19th century comes to life in "The Conspirator," Robert Redford's dramatization of the trial of Mary Surratt and the men who conspired with Booth. James McAvoy and Robin Wright both give stellar performances as a clever young lawyer and a woman railroaded by an angry, vengeful government, but the direction often loses its energy and becomes rather flat and stagey.

In 1865, the Civil War has just ended and the North is celebrating its victory. But then assassins are sent to attack the Secretary of State and the Vice President. And at a play that Lincoln is attending, Booth (Toby Kebbell) shoots the president, shouts "Sic Semper Tyrannis! The South is avenged!" and somehow manages to escape the theatre. The dying Lincoln is taken to a nearby house, and dies shortly after. The conspirators are hunted down, and Booth is killed when they are burned out of the barn where they are hiding.

One of the suspects is Mary Surratt (Wright), the mother of one conspirator and the owner of a boardinghouse where they met. Since the government is determined to punish as many people as possible, she is presumed by everyone -- including former soldier/up-and-coming lawyer Frederick Aiken (McAvoy) -- to be completely guilty.

Then Aiken finds himself in the horrible position of having to defend her, even though he doesn't doubt her guilt. But her innocence or guilt soon become less certain in his mind, even as he realizes that the trial of the suspects is not a true trial -- witnesses are bribed or threatened, and the prosecution refuses to even consider that Mary might not have been a conspirator. As Aiken's life and career fall apart, he throws himself into the last desperate attempts to save her from the hangman's noose.

While obviously the assassination of Lincoln was an important moment in American history, "The Conspirator" looks at the smaller, groundbreaking changes that happened because of it -- namely, the first execution of a white woman by the federal government, and the new right of a civilian trial instead of a merely-a-formality-before-we-hang-everyone military tribunal. It's a sobering reminder that government corruption is nothing new, and that basic rights like a proper trial by one's peers must be fought for constantly, not just once.

As the backdrop to this drama, Redford does an excellent job portraying the fractured, fragile nature of a post-Civil War United States -- there's an undercurrent of seething rage and pain from both sides, glazed over with Washington parties and jaunts to elegant theatres. And the depiction of Lincoln's final hours is absolutely riveting, with the desperate and hysterical citizens crowding outside the building where he dies, surrounded by dead-eyed, hopeless officials and doctors.

Unfortunately, the movie loses a lot of its energy after the first half hour. After that first burst of energy, Mary and the conspirators are all captured and... it simply becomes very very contemplative and stagey, more like a play than a proper movie. Redford doesn't seem to quite know how to inject suspense into the courtroom drama scenes, relying mostly on the occasional outburst from Wright or McAvoy to give it some passion. So for long stretches, it just sort of drags itself along, floating Aiken through subplots that aren't very interesting (such as his visit to Mary's daughter).

McAvoy and Wright both give excellent performances here, as world-weary people who hail from opposite sides of a war that has blistered them both -- he is a fierce young lawyer whose love of justice overrides any blind loyalty to the War Department, and she is a quiet, tormented enigma whose guilt or innocence is never entirely clear. There are some solid performances by Evan Rachel Wood, Colm Meaney, Tom Wilkensen and Danny Huston, but the story effectively revolves around those two actors and the oddly combative chemistry they share.

"The Conspirator" is graced with some excellent performances and a great setting, but Robert Redford's stage-like story seems to lose its momentum after the first half hour, making it a chore to sit through some of the story. A fascinating if flawed story.

Director and producer Robert Redford shows that the debates we have today on the relevancy of Constitutional rights during exceptional times like war or acts of terror are not new, but occupy a significant part of the American experience--although an often ignored part.

The film is based on the true story of the military trial of Mary Surrat, one of the accused conspirators in the Lincoln assassination. Surrat (played by Robin Wright) was unfortunate enough to own the boarding house where several of the conspirators met--including her son. A military court is ordered by Secretary of War Edwin Stanton, one of the most infamous characters in Lincoln's cabinet. It was Stanton who ordered and oversaw, with Lincoln's approval, the mass arrests and imprisonment of thousands of American citizens during the war. Most of those imprisoned were newspaper editors and reporters, anti-war (or anti-Lincoln) Democrats, alleged Southern sympathizers, and simply anyone the government wanted out of the way.

Stanton now orchestrates a kangaroo court to provide an angry and paranoid nation with swift "justice" for the accused and "healing for the nation."

The military court is selected by Stanton. The accused are not allowed to testify in their own defense. Surrat herself is kept in solitary confinement under constant guard. Oddly enough, the attorney chosen to represent Surrat is a former Union war hero lately turned lawyer, Captain Frederick Aiken (James McAvoy). Aiken is chosen by his firm to represent Surrat because he is not a Southerner. He is a reluctant defender completely prejudiced against Surrat at the beginning.

But as the mock trial commences, Aiken is troubled by the complete lack of regard for constitutional protections and due process owed his client. Witnesses are threatened, attorney/client privilege is suspended, and false witnesses are brought forward to accuse Surrat. Aiken becomes disillusioned that the country he fought four years to defend is allowing such a mockery of justice to an American citizen.

Meanwhile, Aiken loses friends daily as war fever rages and anyone not walking in lockstep with Stanton's policies is considered seditious and unpatriotic. At one point, Aiken confronts Secretary Stanton about the injustice of the case, and Stanton reminds him of a primary argument that Lincoln himself used in defending the Civil War: the rights enjoyed by Americans are not as important as the security of the nation itself.

Lincoln was confronted early in the war by opponents in Congress who asked him to justify the multiple constitutional violations being perpetrated by the administration. Lincoln responded that he was violating part of the Constitution in order to prevent the whole of it being violated by the "rebels."

The confusing, purely political logic of Lincoln would be easily flagged by the historian enjoying the advantage of hindsight if Lincoln's position had not later been recycled by Stanton, Woodrow Wilson, FDR, LBJ, Bush I and II, Obama, and basically anyone wanting a trump card over the "Supreme Law of the Land." Americans are historically so conditioned to "exceptions" to Constitutional freedoms and guarantees that the exceptions have become the rule.

Redford shows great wisdom and depth by selecting the Surrat case as the stage on which he presents his audience with the horrible consequences of a "government by expediency." The idolatrous devotion of Americans to the "Lincoln myth" would make it impossible for Redford to make his point had he chosen any number of equally tragic cases that took place prior to Mary Surrat's during the Civil War. But Redford wisely picks an easy moral case. Surrat was a widow and a single parent who was in the wrong place at the wrong time in a post-Lincoln regime governed by easy villains who not one in a thousand Americans could name in a lineup today.

Captain Aiken easily shows that the government can only prove beyond a shadow of doubt that Surrat is guilty of nothing more than being the mother of one of the suspected conspirators. Yet the government argues that the "interests of the nation" must be placed ahead of the rights of the individual. Stanton argues that too much blood has already been shed. If Surrat is freed, then the nation risks further unrest and a continuation of war. It may be wrong to execute Mary Surrat, but it would be worse not to execute her. In the end, the cowardice and fear of men (who should have protected the innocent and weak) allowed Mary Surrat to be hung by the neck until dead.

At the end of the film, Redford inserts a post script before the credits, pointing out that the US Supreme Court ruled one year later (in Ex parte Milligan) that American citizens could not be tried in a military court--even during war time. So the audience is left with some assurance that Surrat's case was a recognized exception and her death not entirely in vain.

But, alas, Redford's charitable desire to provide some relief to his morally indignant audience is muted in those of us who did not fall asleep during our postbellum American history classes. The US Supreme Court ruling in Milligan took place in 1866. But the radical Republican-controlled Congress passed the first of several Reconstruction Acts in 1867. These acts effectively abolished the Southern states, divided the South into five military districts, and put the whole region under marshal law. When Congress feared retribution by the Supreme Court, it simply abolished the Habeus Corpus Act and removed the issue from the Court's jurisdiction. The fit of madness that condemned Mary Surrat to death would last another 10 years. Some believe it has never fully ended.
A great film that may counteract the filmmaker's intentions by illuminating why Constitutional authority, and the rule of law, may be far superior to bullying, morally superior "leadership."

Like most Robert Redford films, this movie about the trial of Lincoln's assassination conspirators is historically meticulous and dramatically rich, but also slow-moving and frequently under-played in key moments. In the extra features, Redford said he was going for a deliberately musty look to the sets, unfortunately resulting in an "Antiques Roadshow" vibe that weighs the film down like a lead ball while leaching the visceral impact of every scene. But the film is certainly well-cast with many familiar TV and cinema faces. James McAvoy is good as the idealistic young lawyer assigned to defend Mary Surratt, a Southern Catholic widow who ran the boarding house where John Wilkes Booth and friends planned the death of Abraham Lincoln, leaving herself as the only female conspirator charged in military court with treason. Redford analogizes the post-assassination backlash of 1865 to present-day abuse of civil liberties. Rather than taking sides for or against Surratt, played here with iron resolve by Robin Wright Penn, Redford lets her remain distant, trying to suggest her guilt and innocence simultaneously. Ironically, the greater historicity here means weakened drama, for which Redford relies on Kevin Kline in a clearly villainous role as War Secretary Edwin Stanton. It creates a weird sense of disconnect to see Stanton consistently played as a villain while Surratt is played as an enigma rather than hero. It's a good film, but not great. Daniel Day-Lewis probably did a better job in "Lincoln" because of his efforts to provide insights into Lincoln's character. This film refuses to give us real insight into anyone except McAvoy, whose gradual transformation comes across here as a touch more self-righteous than genuine. The film should have been about the titular Mary Surratt, not her lawyer.

As a movie: Even judged as a propaganda film, this is a bad movie. For "preaching to the choir", I would give it 3-stars ("It's OK"), but for the general audience, it is 1-star. Because of the script, most of the characters are little more than cardboard cut-outs. Only Robin Wright (as Mary Surratt) has presence as a character. The other main character is her lawyer Frederick Aiken (played by James McAvoy), but his role is primarily to be outraged, thereby serving as a vehicle for preaching at the audience. I quickly developed an unintended dislike for his character, which increased throughout the movie. The scenes are set-pieces and the flow is poor, resulting in a movie that feels slow-paced and meandering. There is no sense of grappling with the issues or alternatives -- there are only pronouncements and posturing. The movie doesn't rise to even the level of a mediocre episode of Law and Order. Also, many of the scenes do not feel authentic (beyond the costumes and sets). First, many of Aiken's diatribes feel incredibly modern, including things that you weren't likely to hear in 1965, much less in 1865 (I am both old enough and young enough to remember the 1960s). Second, the portrayal of the trial feels derivative of too many movies about military (show) trials, reinforcing my assessment below that the script wasn't driven by the history. Examples: Breaker Morant,Paths of Glory. ---- As history: This movie prominently advertises itself as presenting a true story, and this needs to be rebutted. If one watches the documentary in the Extras or reads the history, the kindest thing that can be said is that the movie "was inspired by actual events", or more accurately that it cherry-picked and distorted events. The viewer will likely have the false impression that this was a short, hurried trial (there was a long line of both prosecution and defense witnesses). That there was little evidence of her guilt. That Mary Surratt was badly mistreated, for example being denied visits by her daughter. ... The movie presents images that are virtually guaranteed to be misinterpreted. For example, the prisoners are shown with bags over their heads, invoking parallels to torture. However, those were _padded_ bags and were introduced in response to a suicide attempt, but apparently were also intended to keep the prisoners from communicating with each other. The bags did turn out to be painful, but I haven't seen anything that suggests that was intentional (above the level of the jailers putting on bags more tightly than needed). The documentary (in the Extras) briefly raises the point that much of the controversy about Mary Surratt's guilt was rooted not in the factual evidence, but in sexism -- that a woman wouldn't/couldn't do such a thing. Yet you won't see this in the movie even though it was a significant part of the trial (character witnesses, pleas for clemency, ...). In describing the response to the assassination, one of the movie's historians describes that assassination as unthinkable. Yet there had been multiple assassination attempts against Lincoln, starting before his inauguration. One of those historians repeatedly attributes Mary Surratt's execution to animosity against Catholics, yet never explains (beyond the existence of religious prejudices) and never mentions that there was a large population of Catholics in Maryland -- because it was founded as a colony as a refuge for Catholics (Aside: In case you are wondering, some of my ancestors came to the US as Protestants fleeing Catholics, some as Catholics fleeing Protestants, and some as Protestants fleeing other types of Protestants). One of the historians in the Extras took umbrage at the measures taken to keep the conspirators from escaping on the reasoning that they hadn't yet been convicted. This seems suggestive of the politics underlying the movie. Some of the historians in the documentary seem to be pushing political agendas. One talks about Sec of War Stanton pushing to get "a correct result" as if that was unconnected to justice. Yet the history of the investigation and the trial was one of focusing in on only the most central of the plotters -- many who were unquestionably Confederate sympathizers but were only minor facilitators of the plot were not prosecuted, and not all those convicted were executed. Yet the movie gives the strong impression that the political pressures was to execute persons without concern for their guilt. If so, why include a woman which was bound to be highly controversial? The presentation of the choice to use a military tribunal in both the included documentary and the movie fails to provide even a cursory appreciation for the problems of a civilian trial. For example, until the influx of Northerners during the Civil War, Washington DC was a decidedly Southern city and very pro-slavery (much of the Capitol Building construction used slave labor) and at the time of the trial still had very large pro-Confederacy elements -- the conspirators were hardly alone in this (Aside: neighboring Maryland was a slave state, and although it did not join the Confederacy, much of its population was pro-slavery). In a civilian trial, how would one credibly assemble a jury where there wouldn't be at least one juror who would ignore the facts and instead vote his pro-slavery politics? What would have been the results of a wrongful acquittal of the conspirators? Although the movie is based on the belief that politics determined the verdict, its rendering of the politics of the time is not to be taken seriously. It is minimal, simplistic and mostly wrong. ---- As an allegory: It is hard to believe that this movie is not intended primarily as a comment on military tribunals in the current "Global War on Terror", and was distorted to fill that role. Instead, the Lincoln assassination should be viewed as the opening act in a century of terrorism associated with the Ku Klux Klan (and its predecessors and similar organizations). With the defeat of the Confederate armies, the Union was desperate to keep the rebel troops from melting away and forming guerrilla bands and having the war likely continue for decades. While that was largely prevented, the South stepped down one notch on the insurgency intensity scale and resorted to a widespread campaign of terror to virtually re-institute slavery under other guises and to re-assert the economic and political power of large portions of the old slave-holding class. The North temporarily won the Civil War in 1865, but the South's near-total victory was completed by 1877 (with a few remaining pockets of resistance to be mopped up). Although the trial of Mary Surratt was hardly perfect, it was good-enough and justice was almost certainly done. And it showed a government that could respond effectively and intelligently to an extreme act of terror. It did not wildly and indiscriminately over-react, but implemented a limited, highly targeted response that was open to widespread press coverage and that produced a result that was timely without being rushed. Aside: In choosing to return to a quasi-feudal political and economic system that required the mass of the population -- white and black -- to be kept in poverty, the South consigned itself to be an impoverished region for decades. That system was broken by what could be regarded as the Second Reconstruction: Starting with FDR, the federal government deliberately pumped massive subsidies into the Southern economy (military bases, TVA...). This was followed by education reform, voting rights... So why wasn't this the allegory chosen by Redford et al?? -- Douglas B. Moran

The Conspirator is a star studded period piece concerning the kangaroo court trial of those involved in the Lincoln assassination, specifically the rather thin case against Mary Surratt, played by the usually brilliant Robin Wright. Surratt's son was involved in Booth's numerous revenge plots. Mrs. Surratt owned the boarding house in which the conspirators often met. While there are a number of historical theories and interpretations, the film points out the unconstitutional manner in which the trial was conducted. Historical accuracy or inaccuracy is not my main point of analysis. While obvious characterizations are whole or partially fictitious, the circumstances, Surratt's guilt or innocence and the depth of the pro-Southern conspiracy, are open to historical debate. Therefore, this film is merely an interpretation. However, it is simply flat. Directed by Robert Redford and brimming with talent, it has no logical right to be as lifeless as it felt to me. I can't help but compare it to Spielberg's Lincoln, where political conversation and intrigue is gripping and evocative or Spielberg's earlier historical courtroom drama, Amistad. Compared to those films, the finely crafted sets, costuming, and casting of The Conspirator is dragged down by its lack of passion and its rather drab style. The subject matter is ripe for overblown melodrama or opportunities for taut historical commentary. The Conspirator lands disappointingly in the middle.

Suspend for a moment all this discussion of the history that this film is supposed to revolve around. That "history" is almost immaterial to this film.  The more telling aspect of this film's quality is that American history is not really its source, but rather, Australian Film History.  This film is a poor remake of Bruce Beresford's "Breaker Morant" (1979).  The dialogue of the source movie is sometimes even reproduced.  The courtroom dynamics are nearly identical, with unreliable witnesses that the "green" but bright defense lawyer rips apart.  I suppose Redford was interested in transposing the story to an American context to create an allegory that would critique the Bush years and remind us all how willing we were (and still are) to trample the constitution for public appeasement.  So, fine, there is the producer's motivation, but, then it's his job to make the compelling allegory.  Yes, yes, we get it: the bloodlust for revenge, despite the fact that many people of the era HATED Lincoln (I'm not talking about Southerners--Lincoln was barely re-elected). So fine, there you have the making for ample political allegory, but it does not deliver.  It is too indebted to "Breaker Morant" and not really willing to break out from under its shadow.  In the end, it is what it is:  a fairly transparent remake of a foreign film.  I didn't think "Sommersby" (1993) was that good of a remake either [of "The Return of Martin Guerre" (1982)] but by comparison, "Sommersby" at least holds it own.  This film does not--sadly. Watch "Breaker Morant" instead: that's a hell of a film.

Robert Redford's "The Conspirator" (2010) is about the only woman to be charged as a co-conspirator in Lincoln's assassination. Mary Surratt (Robin Wright) ran the boarding house where her son, John (Johnny Simmons), regularly met with John Wilkes Booth and others plotting their seditious deeds. Mary Claims she simply ran a boarding house and didn't know what her tenants and their friends were hatching. The young lawyer assigned to defend her, Frederick Aiken (James McAvoy), knows that she probably knew more, but also that there's not enough evidence to convict her and, by extension, execute her.

The film starts with Lincoln's assassination and the search for Booth, but then settles into a courtroom drama. I found the first half engrossing enough for a historical drama, but it was the second half that really hooked me in when I discovered that "The Conspirator" wasn't just about the Surratt family. It's just as much about Aiken's determination to do what's right, whatever the cost, and the consequences of this decision.

At only 27 years of age, I'm sure those who assigned Aiken the job of defending Mary Surratt weren't expecting much, especially since he fought for the North and despised the rebellion. He was a puppet expected to just go-through-the-motions of defending Surratt. But, as Aiken discovers that there's really not enough evidence to convict Mary and observes the outright corruption of the prosecution, Aiken understands that there's more than just Mary Surratt's life at stake. If she could be railroaded and executed so easily in the land of the free, anyone could.

But there's a hefty price for doing what's right if it goes against the grain of popular opinion.

Alexis Bledel also stars as Aiken's woman and Evan Rachel Wood as Mary's daughter, both excellent.

The film was shot in Georgia and runs 122 minutes.

FINAL SAY: "The Conspirator" does exactly what a good historical drama should do -- it takes the viewer back into the historical world of the characters and does it effectively and realistically. It also prompts you to look into the facts of the real-life events afterward. Even more, the potent subtexts are driven home.

GRADE: B+

The assassination of Abraham Lincoln at the end of our Civil War was probably one of the most emotionally and politically traumatizing events in our history up to that time. Lincoln, almost universally considered our best and most effective president, had led the country through the War; and Lee's army had just recently surrendered. In the aftermath of assassination, virtually everyone who had any connection to, or association with, John Wilkes Booth, the primary conspirator, was rounded up and incarcerated. There was a government-directed effort to rush to judgement...to get past the trial; punish the offenders; and return the country to normalcy ASAP. To expedite the trial, a military tribunal was used...the civilian perpetrators were tried in a military court, without benefit of trial by jury. Mary Surratt, who ran the boarding house where the conspirators met, was arrested and charged with conspiracy too and this fine historical drama tells her story. One of the conspirators, still at large, was her son, John, and the thinking was that charging and trying his mother would flush him out. It didn't, John Surratt was tried by jury a year later and walked. This is the first film produced by the American Film Company, which was founded on the noble belief that historical films are more compelling than fiction. It was masterfully crafted by Robert Redford behind the camera and features superb performances by Robin Wright as Mary Surratt; and James McAvoy, as her defense lawyer, Frederick Aiken. Evan Rachel Wood, Alexis Bledel, Tom Wilkinson and Kevin Kline deliver fine performances too in support roles. Hopefully this is just the first of other films of this nature to be produced during the sesquicentennial anniversary years of the Civil War. This one carries my highest recommendation.

"The Conspirator" is the first film produced by American Film Company established in 2008, and if you watch the film's end credits closely (or visit the company's homepage), you know the new studio is primarily interested in making historically accurate films based on American history.

The story itself is an intriguing one. Set in post-Civil War Washington, "The Conspirator" is about a young attorney Frederick Aiken (James McAvoy), who reluctantly defends Mary Surratt (Robin Wright), a boarding house owner who was accused of harboring the men responsible for the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.

Directed by Robert Redford, the film spends considerable time following the change that happens in Frederick, from an indifferent and inexperienced young lawyer to a passionate and dedicated one. His transformation is convincing, largely thanks to James McAvoy's effecting performance, but with courtroom drama that often feels rushed, "The Conspirator" as a historical drama sometimes seems not really interested in whether Mary is "guilty" - legally or morally - or not. Some characters like Frederick's friend Sarah Weston (Alexis Bledel) are flat and one-dimensional, making the main plotline a bit melodramatic at times.

Most viewers will notice the message from the director (whose previous effort was a political drama "Lions for Lambs"): a message relevant to the present day, especially the post 9/11 political climate. You will not miss the point, and once you get it, there is not much that will make you think.

I really don't know what to say about "The Conspirator," of which fact-based plot is certainly intriguing, but the result is rather dry. The film is not preachy or dull, but I couldn't help feeling there is a better approach to make a more emotionally charged film out of this historical material.

Great court-room movies are always about more than just the case.  They are usually an intertwining of multiple stories, all of which affect the case itself.  This can be said of this movie.  The title of the movie refers to Mary Surrat, who was tried and convicted of being part of the conspiracy to kill Abraham Lincoln.  Her case and her defense by Union war hero Frederick Aiken is only one key part of the movie.  Another key part is the internal tension within Mr. Aiken in trying to determine her innocence or guilt, and his conflicts with Mary and her daughter in trying to get them to tell him the truth.  This drama itself rivals that of the courtroom.  Smaller story-lines include the conflicts between Mr. Aiken and his peers, which include his girlfriend, his friends at a local gentleman's club, and the machinations of Secretary of War Edwin Stanton.  The movie is anchored by great acting from numerous roles.  Lifelong comic actor Kevin Kline turns in a good performance as Edwin Stanton.  James McAvoy does a wonderful job playing lawyer Frederick Aiken, a character whose internal turmoil is only surpassed by the conflicts he has with those around him.  Probably the best acting is done by the two actresses; Robin Wright playing the "Conspirator", and Evan Rachel Wood playing her daughter.  The former sacrifices herself to protect her son, who she knows was intimately involved in a plot to kidnap President Lincoln.  The latter is convinced to turn against her brother to try and save her mother; to no avail.  All told, a great drama set in the aftermath of two of the most important events in US history; the Civil War and the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.

I do not know if it is accurate to all the events and circumstances however the actors are top notch and the directing of the movie couldn't have been better. A story about injustice and how far men in power will go to achieve the goals they see fit. The truth doesn't matter to such men. Their goals must be reached at all costs even to the sacrifice of their own duty to God and country.

What an amazing movie. Despite of the fact that injustice reigned after Lincoln's death, this movie make you think on the need that we all need for REAL Justice. Very well made, great photography, actors and the plot could not be better. 10 stars if it was possible.
